 HyperNEAT Generative Encoding
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=gJyR9pE3nH82SsCRG6kPeLLE7B_GFlOfVFampVGtVL_g7mbg1gbc
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

> Jeff, by the way, congrats on the quadruped paper! I hope it helps
> others evolve ambulating creatures with HyperNEAT as well.  It really
> helps to have the example you have now provided that shows how such a
> substrate might be set up.

Thanks! 

Please see my responses below.

> I think it's difficult to find a good benchmark.  There are some
> publications citing successful biped walking, such as Reil and
> Husbands, but no one seems to be able to reproduce their results with
> the same setup.  In fact, I have never heard of anyone reproducing
> their results although I know several who have tried; I would be
> interested to hear from anyone who has.  There are some other works
> that produced bipeds as well, though I don't know the citations
> offhand.  But they usually involve some kind of hand-designed aspect
> or a "hand of God," which means something that holds the biped up
> while it is learning, kind of like training wheels.  That makes
> comparison with such systems kind of apples and oranges if you don't
> apply such techniques.  And I think ideally we'd like to be able to
> just tell evolution to go and let it do its own thing.
> 
> Given the anecdotal difficulty of the problem, for now I would
> consider it a success to get any biped to walk without any special
> tricks.  I do not see the biped so much as a benchmark as I see it a
> gateway to more interesting domains.  If you can evolve a biped, then
> you can probably evolve a lot of other creatures and also make bipeds
> that do increasingly interesting things.  It also validates a method's
> ability to produce complex controllers.

I agree with all of that. We ran into the same issues with quadrupeds.

> Yes, recurrence is necessary to get oscillations with leaky
> integrators, which brings up an interesting issue for HyperNEAT: The
> substrate must include some sort of recurrence in its architecture.  I
> don't think many aside from Peter have played with recurrent
> substrates.  Of course, it should be possible and interesting to try.

We have tried the quadruped problem here with recurrence. Interestingly,
recurrence hurt HyperNEAT and helped P-NEAT.

> Like I said, at the moment our focus is not on comparison.  What we
> want is a concrete understanding of the domain: What makes it hard,
> what are the keys to making it work, what makes it most interesting,
> etc.  Perhaps we will think about comparison later.  But I think at
> the moment the interesting question is why so many have trouble with
> this problem.  Even Tyler Streeter only got his biped to walk a few
> steps before falling.  We want to master the domain completely so that
> in the future anyone can play with it easily and use it as a gateway
> to more interesting and complex control problems.

I hope you accomplish that goal!

I am surprised to hear you say that Tyler Streeter only got his robot to
walk a few steps. In this video, the final gait seems very stable and takes
15 steps before the end of the clip:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TulriQmSC_U&feature=related

Thanks again for the kind words about my work.
